nodes.bodyText: Sorry I guess that was cherry picked from my commit, we should revert that (this file in general)

I think dropped should also occur when you get exceptions that are unexpected, if I understood correctly - i.e. could not reach upstream should mark it as dropped, according to the docs. Do we want to do this here? I think at the moment we wouldn't, it would be caught by RuntimeException, and wasDropped would remain false, or...?
Dropped requests results in updating limits. So I think in our case only Timeouts are relevant.
If a broker is causing a lot of errors, it could be beneficial to also starve it out, no? Though we could do this in further iterations as well 👍
Let's remove the TODO
Can we configure the limit via environment variables?
I can add them if it is required.
Didn't we decide on making the default half of this? e.g. Math.floor(gatewayCfg.getCluster().getRequestTimeout().toMillis(), 2)?
Yes. I am not yet 100% sure what is a good default value. So I left it as it is. But I will make it half.
Did we ever figure out if other exceptions may be thrown that would be transient and would not indicate that we should stop?

Interface documentation doesn't say much. It only says if it throws exception we should call onError() to terminate the stream. Looking at the implementation it can throw also IllegalStateException if the stream is already aborted or completed.

So the docs says we should call onError on exception, but also calling on error will throw an exception if the call is already closed? I assume that includes if it was cancelled by the client? That seems...counter intuitive.
Regardless, if the call was cancelled (which we can know based on the status if there is one), shouldn't we stop trying other partitions?
Yes. We stop trying other partition.
Are there any possible downsides to suppressing the exception? Could we miss out on useful information?

I guess no problem. Activated jobs are already sent to the client. If there was any problem there it will be logged. This is called only to close the stream. I don't think it is much useful to log failure here.
Random realization - shouldn't jobTypeToNextPartitionId be thread-safe? Right now it's just a normal hash map? Or am I missing something? Isn't this handler potentially called from multiple threads?
Can we use assertThatThrownBy (or whatever the name is) instead of the expected exception?

Also aren't we returning a better exception than ExecutionException? In the cause I guess it should be ResourceExhausedException? I'd prefer matching on the exception type than the message, if possible.
Matching with ResourceExhaustedException did not work. I didn't check at what point it is converted to ExecutionException.
Do we want to disable refresh by default? I guess this wasn't on purpose
I initially passed everything out of convenience, can we limit it to what is needed? So backpressure config and request timeout?

Let's keep the env var as they would be in 0.24 to ease upgrading.
Rules are that every _ is a nested level, so zeebe.gateway.backpressure.enabled = ZEEBE_GATEWAY_BACKPRESSURE_ENABLED, but zeebe.gateway.backpressure.aimd.minLimit = ZEEBE_GATEWAY_BACKPRESSURE_AIMD_MINLIMIT. And same for the ones below; it's sufficient to just change the values, the constant names can be whatever.
I know it's mostly for testing, but let's stay consistent and also allow configuring it via env var, it's pretty cheap to do so.
Did we confirm this work as expected with the filtering? We could also go for a less modern approach and just create here an array of partitions 🤷‍♂️ This iterator approach feels a little overblown 😅
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -18,10 +20,20 @@
   private final OfInt iterator;
   private int currentPartitionId;
 
-  public PartitionIdIterator(final int startPartitionId, final int partitionsCount) {
+  public PartitionIdIterator(
+      final int startPartitionId,
+      final int partitionsCount,
+      final BrokerTopologyManager topologyManager) {
     iterator =
         IntStream.range(0, partitionsCount)
-            .map(index -> ((index + startPartitionId) % partitionsCount) + START_PARTITION_ID)
+            .map(
+                index ->
+                    (index + startPartitionId - START_PARTITION_ID) % partitionsCount
+                        + START_PARTITION_ID)
+            .filter(
+                p ->
+                    topologyManager.getTopology().getLeaderForPartition(p)

nodes.bodyText: I have this one test which I missed to commit. It more or less tests this.
